content: on this video www knittinghelp com/video/play/grafting-garter-kitchener-stitch when there are only 2 stitches left one on the front needle and the other on the back needle go into the front stitch knitwise and slide it off the front needle then go into the back stitch knitwise and slide it off the needle please note if you are more comfortable using the standard stockinette kitchener stitch please feel free to do so since it is such a small area to be grafted it won t make much difference one way or the other to be frank with the right-side of the shawl facing you pass the tail through the remaining 3 stitches from right to left removing the holder or locking marker and snug it weave in the tail and then using a dpn or tapestry needle redistribute the gauge as necessary to neaten up the join area blocking soak the shawl in warm water using a gentle wool wash for about 20 minutes then roll it in a towel to remove the excess water weave blocking wires through the yarn overs across the top of the shawl and stretch it to the size you prefer making sure both sides are equal in length using rustproof t-pins pin the wires in 2 5 cm increments to secure the top pin out each point of the lace edge across the top of the wingspan stretch and then pin out the bottom tip so the spine measures about half the width of the wingspan on each side use a yardstick held diagonally between the top and bottom tips to determine how far to pin the points along the two side edges pin a few points on one side and pin the same points on the opposite side repeat until all points are pinned if blocked aggressively your shawl will have deep scallops and pointy points block until dry unpin and snip any yarn tails as the final step this original pattern is intended for
